Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\), where L is a differential operator. We investigate the role of a Fourier transform, defined by \\(F(u)(k) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-ikx} u(x, t) dx\\), applied to the function u(x, t).

If the Fourier transform \\(F\\) is applied to the initial condition \\(u(x, 0)\\) and then allowed to evolve according to \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) without further intervention, will the transformed system's state \\(F(u)(k, t)\\) at time t = T be equivalent to simply transforming the state \\(u(x, T)\\) directly?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform to the initial condition and allowing evolution under L will affect the system differently than directly transforming at a later time. The evolution of u under L and its interaction with different wavenumbers k, determined by the Fourier transform, will generally produce different outcomes when comparing these two processes.
